PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  Project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is required in order to produce a mutually 
agreeable project suitable for Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing. The PPTA will (i) review 
the project component plans and designs, and suggest ways to enhance the quality of the project; 
(ii) help define the scope, design, and operating plan of the proposed railway bypass line; (iii) 
ensure that the executing agency (EA) and implementing agencies (IAs) have the capacity to 
successfully implement the project and conduct any training or capacity development required to 
ensure such capacity; (iv) validate the feasibility studies; (v) conduct the economic and financial 
analysis;  (vi)  in  cooperation  with  the  EA,  determine  areas  where  the  PPTA  will  support  the 
transport  sector  in  Ulaanbaatar  and  enhance  the  benefits  delivered  by  the  proposed  project 
components; and (vii) ensure that the EA adheres to ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) 
covering resettlement, the environment, and to ADB’s social and gender policy during project 
planning and preparation.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement 
 
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $1,500,000 equivalent which will be financed on a grant 
basis through ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund-V (TASF-V). The government will provide 
counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  suitable  furnished  office  accommodation  with  utilities, 
telecommunications  access,  materials,  maps,  data  and  documents  required  by  the  PPTA 
counterpart professional staff, support staff, and other in-kind contributions. The government was 
advised that the approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The 
detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  The PPTA will be implemented using an international consulting firm in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). An association 
with suitable domestic consultants is encouraged to complement consultant's local knowledge and 
experience. It is anticipated that the following international and national staff will be required:

5.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described below. 
 
6.  Railway  Engineers  (international,  9  person-months;  national,  10  person-months).  The 
consultants will (i) carry out site inspections to identify main engineering issues, (ii) identify the 
most suitable track alignment, (iii) identify station location and prepare preliminary station designs, 
(iv)  recommend  technical  standards  and  design  conditions,  (v)  develop  implementation 
arrangements for project management, and (vi) assist in the preparation of a procurement plan. 
 
7.  Procurement specialists (international, 3 person-months; national, 5 person-months). The 
procurement  specialist  is  required  to  be  familiar  with  ADB’s  procurement  guidelines  and 
procedures. The specialist will be responsible for (i) assessing procurement capacity of the EA/IA, 
(ii)  assist  the  EA/IA  in  preparing  the  procurement  plan,  (iii)  support  procedures  in  advance 
contracting, and (iv) provide capacity development activities on procurement to the EA/IA. 
 
8.  Traffic forecast and economic specialists (international, 2 person-months; national, 2 
person months). In line with ADB guidelines and reference documents on cost-benefit analysis,1 
the consultants will (i) conduct least cost analysis of alignment options, (ii) assess project rationale 
and its role in the logistics chain for both freight and passenger traffic, (iii) identify rail traffic growth 
factors, (iv) analyze railway operating costs, (v) identify and quantify the economic benefits of 
increasing railway traffic efficiency, (vi) define total investment cost estimate, (vii) undertake cost-
benefit evaluation of the project to determine internal rate of return and net present value, and (viii) 
identify and evaluate project risks. 
 
9.  Financial specialists (international, 2 person-months; national, 2 person-months). The 
consultants are preferably a Chartered Accountant or Certified Public Accountant and a member of 
a professional accounting entity. The consultants will (i) prepare cost estimates, financing plan and 
financial  cost-benefit  analysis  of  the  project,  (ii)  prepare  financial  projections  of  project 
components, (iii) carry out financial management assessment, and (iv) develop the design and 
funds flow and disbursement mechanisms for the ensuing project. 
 
10.  Social development and resettlement specialist (international, 2.5 person-months); The 
consultant will (i) provide oversight and guidance in conducting social safeguards due diligence, (ii) 
assist the EA in preparing resettlement plan, (iii) undertake consultations with the project affected 
persons, (iv) review organizational structure and capacity for resettlement implementation, (v) 
develop livelihood restoration plan based on the outcomes of consultation process, (vi) assess 
project impacts on the indigenous peoples, (vii) conduct gender analysis and assess the degree to 
which the project could provide gender benefits, and (viii) prepare the social analysis and social 
development action plan. 
 
11.  Social  development  specialist  (national,  2.5  person-months).  The  consultant  will  (i) 
conduct a poverty and social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social 
Analysis (2012), (ii) identify key stakeholders and their project related interests, (iii) assess the role 
of civil society organizations in the design, preparation and implementation of the project, (iv) 
conduct gender analysis with the aim to develop the project as “some gender elements” category, 
(v) prepare the poverty and social analysis, and (vi) assist in preparing the social development and 
action plan. 
 
12.  Resettlement  specialist  (national,  3  person-months).  The  consultant  will  (i)  identify 
alternative alignments or designs to avoid or minimize the amount of land required for project

implementation, (ii) conduct socioeconomic impact assessment of the resettlement, (iii) assist the 
EA in conducting census of affected households, (iv) assess the policy and legal framework for 
resettlement with respect to the policies and regulations of the Government of Mongolia, (v) assess 
and  verify  that  the  compensation  standards  are  based  on  replacement  cost,  (vi)  assist  in 
developing ‘grievance redress mechanism’ to receive and facilitate resolution of affected persons’ 
concerns, and (vii) assist in developing an effective consultation mechanism. 
 
13.  Environment specialists (international, 3 person-months; national, 5 person-months). The 
consultants will (i) assist the EA to carry out further investigations and analysis, as required, to 
prepare the Environment Impact Assessment (EIA), Environmental Management Plan (EMP) and 
Environmental  Assessment  and  Review  Framework  (EARF)  for  all  project  components,  in 
accordance  with  the  guidance  in  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  as  well  as  the 
requirements of the Government of Mongolia, and (ii) co-ordinate with other PPTA consultants to 
optimize  the  alignment,  design,  construction,  and  operation  and  maintenance  proposals  to 
minimize environmental impacts. It is assumed that the Government will handle all aspects of the 
domestic environmental approvals and adequate baseline studies will be carried out and be made 
available prior to the PPTA to inform the EIA, EMP and EARF for approval by ADB. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The EA is the Ministry of Road and Transport. The EA will support the proposed PPTA 
through in-kind contributions of counterpart staff and related expenses. Disbursements under the 
PPTA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Any procurement under this PPTA will be conducted in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to time). The PPTA 
will commence on 1 Sept 2015 and end on 31 December 2016.
